Review Redox-active polymer electrode materials for potassium storage: Structure design, electrochemical performance, and storage mechanism Ying Fang Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Resources Data curation a Guo-Yu Zhu Writing – original draft a Ning-Ning Zhu Writing – original draft a Ji-Miao Xiao Writing – original draft a Zi-Jian Yi Writing – original draft a Bai-Hua Huang Writing – review & editing a Bo Wang Writing – review & editing a Lin Liu Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Conceptualization b ⁎ De-Shan Bin Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Supervision Project administration Conceptualization a ⁎ Dan Li Writing – review & editing a a College of Chemistry and Materials Science, Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Supramolecular Coordination Chemistry, Jinan University, Guangzhou 510632, Guangdong, China College of Chemistry and Materials Science Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Supramolecular Coordination Chemistry Jinan University Guangzhou Guangdong 510632 China College of Chemistry and Materials Science, Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Supramolecular Coordination Chemistry, Jinan University, Guangzhou 510632, Guangdong, China b School of Materials and Energy, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou 510006, Guangdong, China School of Materials and Energy Guangdong University of Technology Guangzhou Guangdong 510006 China School of Materials and Energy, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou 510006, Guangdong, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract This review outlines the advances of redox-active polymer electrode for K-ion storage with discussion on the material designs, battery performances, storage mechanism, and structure–function correlations. Benefiting from the low cost and high abundance of potassium resources, K-based batteries have attracted numerous research interest as a more sustainable battery chemist, particularly when considering the enormous demand for sustainable energy storage while limiting Li sources for Li-based batteries. However, the much larger size of the K-ion usually leads to the serious electrodes’ volumetric expansion with rapid capacity fading, making the pursuit of electrodes for potassium storage with high capacity and high stability a significant challenge. The polymer electrode materials have been considered promising materials to address these issues due to their porous characteristics, insolubility in electrolytes, and flexible structural design at a molecular level. In this review, we outline the recent advancements in redox-active polymer electrodes, including anode and cathode, materials for K-based batteries, including crystalline porous coordination polymers, crystalline covalent organic polymers, amorphous polymers, and polymer composites. We discuss the electrode designs, electrochemical performances, and K-ion storage mechanism, with a focus on their structure–function correlations. With this knowledge, we propose the perspectives and challenges in designing advanced polymer electrode materials for K-based batteries. We expect this review will shed light on the further development of reliable polymer electrode materials. Keywords K-based battery Polymer electrode materials Electronic conductivity Solubility Battery performance 1 Introduction The growing demand for large-scale energy storage has driven a significant surge in the need for lower-cost and more sustainable batteries. Although Li-ion batteries (LIBs) have emerged as the preferred energy storage devices due to their high energy density [1–3], the uneven distribution and limited resource of lithium resource (0.0017 wt%) have led to concerns on not only the cost but also the sustainability of Li resource [4]. To alleviate the concern, various battery technologies have been pursued as alternatives to LIBs. Among various new rechargeable batteries, the K-based, typically K-ion batteries (KIBs) with a similar working mechanism to LIBs, have shown the advantages of abundant resources (1.5 wt%) and lower redox potential of K+/K. Especially, it is found that the K+/K redox couple was lower than that of Na+/Na and even that of Li+/Li in the electrolyte of KPF6 in ethylene carbonate (EC): diethyl carbonate (DEC), endowing KIBs with the potential of wide voltage window and high energy density (Fig. 1 a, b) [5–9]. In addition, K+ features a much smaller Stokes’ radius (3.6 Å) compared to Na+ (4.6 Å) and Li+ (4.8 Å) (Fig. 1c), promising faster ion mobility and ion conductivity in the electrolyte [10]. Inspired by these advantages, intense efforts have been devoted to exploring reliable electrode materials for building advanced KIBs [11]. However, due to the significantly larger size of K+ with a radius of 1.38 Å than that for Li+ (0.76 Å) and Na+ (1.02 Å), the intercalation of K+ would induce a much more serious volume change of electrode, leading to the structural collapse of the electrode together with rapid capacity fading [12–16]. Moreover, the larger size and heavy mass of K+ might lead to its sluggish transfer kinetics in the interphase and electrode inside. Accordingly, the pursuit of electrodes for potassium storage with high capacity and high stability remains a formidable challenge. Different inorganic electrode materials showed significant applied implications in K-based batteries. However, some inorganic materials have only limited room for structure and function design. In addition, inorganic electrode materials, with the storage mechanism of alloy-, conversion-type, and de-intercalation processes during potassiation/depotassiation, will induce structural changes for poor cycling performance [17,18]. As a result, interest in organic electrode materials has increased. Organic electrode materials, existing as small molecules or polymers, are currently drawing considerable research interest in KIBs due to their resource abundance, high redox activity, and large room for function designability. The electrochemical behavior of organic materials usually depends on the surface-dominated storage of K-ion, which usually facilitates the faster K-ion transfer with much lower volume deformation than that for the deintercalation-type, conversion-type, and alloy-type electrodes. The introduction of redox groups in the organic molecules like NN, CO, and CN could usually act as the storage site for K-ion, providing the possibility of achieving high K-ion storage capacity. Unfortunately, for the small molecule electrodes, their easy dissolution in organic electrolytes (Fig. 2 a) and low electronic conductivity would plague their applications in non-aqueous rechargeable KIBs. To address these issues, Building the redox-active units into the polymeric frameworks was widely explored, which is demonstrated to be very effective at limiting their dissolution (Fig. 2b) and even significantly enhancing the K+/e− transfer when conductive porous polymers were designed. Over the past years, numerous research efforts have increasingly focused on developing polymeric structures, such as metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), covalent organic frameworks (COFs), amorphous polymer, and polymer composite, as illustrated in Fig. 3 for the time axis of the representative development [21–28]. Typically, crystalline porous polymer materials, such as MOFs and COFs have attracted significant interest in electrochemical energy storage systems. Both MOFs and COFs are highly designable with the functional unit to get the rich active site with open pores and channels formed by strong bonds between the building blocks [3,29,30]. The molecular engineering enables the optimization of redox activity, charge transport dynamics, and dissolution resistance [23,31–33]. They also distinguish themselves from others, such as the connected way of their chemical bonds and the complexity of fabrication. MOFs, which consist of redox-active metal ions or clusters coordinated with functional organic ligands [34], show desirable pore structure, crystallinity, and insolubility in organic electrolytes, making them promising for electrode materials of large-size K+ storage [35,36]. COFs, linked by covalent bonds and usually free from metal, have also been explored for application in energy storage systems [25,37]. Except for the crystalline porous polymeric framework, the amorphous-polymer materials are also utilized due to the facile and efficient fabrication [38–40]. Due to their unordered stacked structure, the amorphous-polymer electrode materials can also enable rapid diffusion of K+ to active sites, contributing to sufficient kinetics even at low temperatures [41]. More importantly, it could facilely introduce the highly active species into the polymeric framework to enhance the battery's performance, particularly the specific capacity. For example, the polyacrylonitrile (PAN) polymer possesses high flexibility and electrical conductivity. It can be transformed into S-PAN (sulfur-doped polyacrylonitrile) composite through pyrolysis with short-chain sulfur which could function as the high redox-active materials for K-ion storages [42–44]. This review outlines the recent progress in the redox-active polymer materials as anode and cathodes for K-ion storages in multiple aspects including the structure designs, electrochemical performances, storage mechanisms. The polymer electrode materials including the crystalline porous one like MOFs, COFs, amorphous polymers, and the polymer composites. We discuss the structure designs with emphasis in how to introduce more active sites for K-ion storage meanwhile achieving the high structure stability. The battery performances of the HCNs were discussed with focus on the structure-performance relationship. The K-ion storage mechanisms were also be summarized to with focus on the transfer behavior, the active sites, and the storage location, to have a better understanding of the electrode stability and kinetics. Finally, we discussed the opportunities and challenges for the further development of the functional polymer electrode materials for K-ion storages. We expect this contribution could provide useful guidelines for the further development of polymer electrode materials for KIBs. 2 MOFs electrode materials MOFs, an emerging class of coordination polymers, offer innovative solutions to this dissolution problem through their unique structural and functional attributes. As coordination polymer constructed through organic connecting units and metal centers, MOFs have the features of high porosity, extensive surface area, and adaptable structure [45–49]. Therefore, MOFs shows great potential in energy storage, catalysis, gas separation, etc. due to its unique porous structure. Such porous structure not only facilitates the transport of K-ions, but also ensures the effectiveness and high density of active sites. Furthermore, the versatility of MOFs could enables further optimization of electrode' electrochemical performance by tailoring their structure and composition, achieving enhanced energy density and extended cycle life for K-ion storage [50]. Typically, Hu and co-workers [51] reported a layered MOF as anode materials for KIBs. This layered MOF was synthesized from terephthalic acid and CoCl2·6H2O through a typical solvothermal method, and was named L-Co2(OH)2BDC. This layered structure can reduce the distance for K-ions' access to the active center site and provide a cavity for electrolyte infiltration. The synthesized L-Co2(OH)2BDC exhibits high reversible capacities, reaching 246 mA h g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 and 214 mA h g−1 at 0.2 A g−1, with Coulombic efficiencies approaching 100%. Notably, even at a high current density of 1 A g−1, it retains a substantial reversible capacity of 188 mA h g−1 after 600 cycles. This excellent and stable performance mainly depends on two aspects: (1) The Co center and organic ligands in the constructed MOF are involved in potassium storage, which makes the active sites increased in number and density; (2) During the charge and discharge process, it was observed that the local coordination environment around oxygen ions changes reversibly with the insertion/extraction of K-ion, and this coordination relationship significantly ensures the reversibility of the insertion and extraction of K-ions. The MOF (MIL-125(Ti)) material reported by Feng and co-workers [28] is also used as an anode material for KIBs, but different from the layered MOF studied by Hu's team, MIL-125(Ti) does not require the direct participation of metal central ions in the potassiation/depotassiation process. MIL-125(Ti) stores K-ions via its organic ligand part. During the electrochemical working process, Ti ions do not directly participate in the storage of K-ions. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), MIL-125(Ti) is formed by the coordination bond between terephthalic acid as the organic connecting unit and Ti ions as the metal central nodes. Due to its inherently porous characteristics, MIL-125(Ti) has an average pore diameter of 1.60 nm, enabling it to demonstrate exceptional electrochemical properties within carbonate electrolyte systems. A capacity of 208 mA h g−1 can be obtained at a current of 0.01 A g−1, while at a high current of 0.2 A g−1, the capacity can be maintained at 90.2% and the Coulombic efficiency is approximately 100% after 2000 cycles. In view of the urgent need for efficient energy storage technology in certain high-temperature environments, it is particularly critical to develop high-temperature rechargeable batteries with excellent thermal stability and high performance. However, increasing the operating temperature of the battery accelerates the mechanical and chemical instability of the anode of KIBs, resulting in a rapid reduction of battery capacity and rate performance. Because of the instability and performance degradation problems that battery systems face under high-temperature conditions, developing high-temperature potassium-ion battery electrode materials that can withstand extreme temperatures and maintain efficient operation has undoubtedly become a very challenging scientific research task. For this reason, Teng and co-workers [52] demonstrated that considerable stability at high temperatures could be achieved by using MOF-5 as an anode material for K-ion batteries. Like MOF (MIL-125(Ti)), the MOF-5 developed by them also does not require a metal center to participate directly in the electrochemical process of potassium storage (Fig. 4b). They synthesized 0MOF-5, 2MOF-5, 3MOF-5 and 4MOF-5 by adjusting the deionized water content in the preparation process of MOF-5 (the deionized water content was 0, 2, 3 and 4 mL, respectively). Afterward, they conducted electrochemical tests using 3MOF-5 as an example. At the set operating temperature of 62.5 °C, the KIBs exhibit initial discharge and charge capacities of 1183 and 210 mA h g−1, respectively, at 0.2 A g−1. Over 150 cycles, they maintain a capacity of 160 mA h g−1 with minimal decay of 0.15% per cycle. Even at a higher current density of 0.5 A g−1, they deliver a reversible capacity of 56 mA h g−1 over 3000 cycles, experiencing a negligible decay of 0.018% per cycle (Fig. 4c). The improved cycle stability performance observed at high temperatures is attributed to the fulfillment of the following two critical conditions: (1) The porous structure of the synthesized MOF and the formation of the solid electrolyte interface during the electrochemical reaction make significant contributions to the excellent cycle durability of KIB. (2) A novel energy storage mechanism, that is, the CO bond serves as a redox center, which can effectively control or reduce the volume fluctuation or change during the electrochemical charge and discharge process. Unfortunately, although polymers such as MOFs were used to solve the solubility problem and improve cycle stability, the inherent poor conductivity of MOFs resulted in low capacity in the above work. To overcome this limitation, the integration of transition metal ions with conjugated organic ligands in a planar structure, forming coordination bonds, has been explored. This method allows the built MOF to exhibit robust planar conjugation and minor π-π stacking interactions outside the plane, thereby facilitating rapid electron transfer and enhancing conductivity [54]. Along this line, two-dimensional conductive MOFs (2D c-MOFs) have been widely studied due to their high conductivity and porosity (Fig. 5 a, b). The 2D c-MOF unit has three different oxidation states and exhibits amazing redox activity (Fig. 5b). The synthesis of 2D c-MOF requires suitable organic ligands and metal centers, as well as bases and oxidants (Fig. 5c) [53]. At the same time, due to the unique charge transport modes of two-dimensional c-MOF, such as band and hopping conduction and path transport in bonds and space, it can rapidly transport K-ions and enhance its conductivity [53]. Because of the unique structural construction and charge transport method, the conductive 2D c-MOFs have the advantages of high conductivity, porosity, redox activity, and stability. Inspired by the high conductivity and stability of 2D c-MOF, Wang and co-workers [55] synthesized two-dimensional conjugated metal–organic frameworks (2D c-MOFs) with different topologies by regulating the composition of the reaction solvent. Using the novel π-conjugated octahydroxyl tetrabenzoanthracene (8OH-TBA) with a four-arm core as the organic ligands, they successfully synthesized the rhombus-structured sql-Cu-TBA-MOF which served as the cathode for KIBs. The calculated structure reveals that the synthesized sql-Cu-TBA-MOF possesses a pore size of approximately 1.31 nm. Interestingly, theoretical calculations have proven that each [CuO4] unit in the sql-Cu-TBA-MOF can be combined with three cations (K+) and one anion (PF−). At the same time, sql-Cu-TBA-MOF has three K-ion diffusion pathways: layer-to-layer, layer-within-plane, and along the layer. Among them, the layer-to-layer diffusion energy is lower than the other two, so the K-ion transport rate increases. At the same time, due to the larger size of K-ion, the interlayer spacing increases during the intercalation process, exposing the active sites. Owing to their unparalleled topology and different potassium storage sites, the sql-Cu-TBA-MOF cathode for KIBs exhibits superior electrochemical properties. At 0.2 A g−1, the sql-Cu-TBA-MOF still has a high discharge specific capacity of 178.4 mA h g−1 and excellent cyclability (it can be cycled more than 9,000 times at 10.0 A g−1). Unexpectedly, even at −20 °C, the positive electrode of sql-Cu-TBA-MOF still has great electrochemical performance. Benefiting from the excellent conductivity of 2D c-MOF and the redox activity of [CuO4] units, Wang and co-workers [56] revealed the innovative application of a 2D c-MOF and dual active sites (Cu-HATNH) constructed using hexaazanonaphthalene (HATN). To maximize its potential, Cu-HATNH is combined with carbon nanotubes to form a composite material (Cu-HATNH@CNT), which is used as a high-performance KIBs cathode material. Because this structure increases the effectiveness of active sites, Cu-HATNH@CNT has a high initial capacity of 317.5 mA h g−1 at 0.1 A g−1, and it retains an impressive 96.8% of its capacity (at 5 A g−1) even after undergoing 2200 cycles. Like sql-Cu-TBA-MOF, Cu-HATNH@CNT also stores K-ions through the multi-electron redox reaction of the unsaturated [CuO4] unit. The additional advantage of Cu-HATNH@CNT is that it can also store K-ions through the multi-electron reaction of the CN bond in the HATNH unit. In addition to CNTs, other conductive matrix, including graphene, carbon black, or even the conductive polymer may also be compounded with the active COF to enhance the electronic conductivity. Bin and co-workers [23] demonstrated the significant applied implications of conductive MOF with π-d conjugation for high-performance KIBs anode (Fig. 6 a), which involved the interaction between the π orbitals of the aromatic molecules and the d orbitals of the copper ions. They used nitrogen-rich hexaazatrinaphthalene as the organic ligand and CuO4 as the metal center to construct a porous conductive MOF (HAN-Cu-MOF). This innovative structure not only can overcome the shortcomings of organic electrode materials, namely blocking dissolution in organic electrolytes (Fig. 6b), but also withstands the volume expansion problem caused by the potassization/depotassization process due to its strict structure. This MOF not only shows high conductivity, but can also deliver excellent redox activity and stability at high operating temperatures (60 °C). HAN-Cu-MOF exhibits outstanding rate performance at elevated current density and temperature (60 °C, Fig. 6e). This MOF as the anode can endure the repeated potassiation/depotassiation with a reversible capacity of 238 mA h g−1 at 0.5 A g−1 after 1000 cycles, with a high capacity retention of 95.8% (an extremely low decay rate of only 0.0042% per cycle). Also, after 1600 cycles at 1 A g−1, it retains 96.7% capacity (202.4 mA h g−1), fading just 0.0021% per cycle (Fig. 6f). Such excellent performance depends on the rich and effective active sites brought by the CN group and CuO4 metal unit in the HAN organic ligand (Fig. 6c, d). At the same time, the porous network structure of MOF allows charges to pass quickly. Overall, MOF materials with designed active sites and robust structures show significant applied implications for K-ion storages, and a summary of representative MOFs for KIBs has been illustrated in Table 1 . 3 COF electrode materials COFs, similar to MOFs, are crystalline polymer materials but composed of organic units through covalent bonds [57]. COFs not only have the advantages of designable chemical structure, rich pore structure, and huge specific surface area [25,58–62], but also possess unique properties, including the usual absence of expensive transition metals, light molecular weight, high energy density, and significant cost-effectiveness [63]. Accordingly, COFs have inspired extensive research interests in the field of K-based batteries (Table 2 ). Compared with MOF materials [64], COF materials have shown better chemical stability in various solvents, which undoubtedly shows attractive application prospects [65]. However, the development of COF as an electrode for K-based batteries is still in its infancy. It faces challenges such as few active sites, low active site utilization, many side reactions caused by large specific surface area, and unstable electrode–electrolyte interface [24]. Moreover, the inherent low conductivity of COF, coupled with the presence of defects that impair electron transfer, necessitates that the active sites within its framework do not achieve full interaction with charges. To solve the problem of low conductivity of COF materials, Wang and co-workers [25] designed the polycondensation of 4,4′-biphenyldiboronic acid (BPDA) and 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexahydroxytriphenylene (HHTP) on the CNT surface and successfully synthesized the boronic ester based COF (COF-10@CNT). The few-layer structure of COF-10@CNT significantly promotes the transmission efficiency of K+ and effectively alleviates the huge volume expansion problem caused by the charge and discharge process. In addition, the material achieves the storage of K-ions through the π-cation interaction between K+ and the conjugated π electrons on the benzene ring. These unique advantages jointly endow COF-10@CNT with excellent electrochemical properties. After 500 cycles at 0.1 A g−1, COF-10@CNT can reach a specific capacity of 288 mA h g−1, showing excellent potassium storage performance, and a long cycle life of 4000 cycles at 1 A g−1 with a specific capacity of 161 mA h g−1. Wu et al. [29] prepared a polyimide COF composite (P-COF@SWCNT) by in situ condensation of naphthalene-1,4,5,8-tetracarboxylic dianhydride (NTCDA) and tris (4-aminophenyl) amine (TAPA) on single-walled carbon nanotubes for use as an anode of K-ion batteries (Fig. 7 a). The P-COF@SWCNT anode exhibits a very high reversible capacity of 438 mA h g−1 at 0.05 A g−1. Moreover, the rate performance of P-COF@SWCNT at various current densities significantly surpasses that of P-COF. When the current density returns to 0.05 A g−1, P-COF@SWCNT can still have a capacity retention rate of 75% (Fig. 7c). P-COF@SWCNT can maintain 114 mA h g−1 at 0.7 A g−1 despite being cycled 1400 times (Fig. 7d). It is precisely because the framework structure of P-COF itself solves the problem of dissolution of small organic molecules and enhances the ability of electron transmission through the introduction of SWCNT that P-COF@SWCNT has good stability. At the same time, due to the peeling caused by ductile graphite technology. The structure exposes more active sites in the treated COF, shortens the ion diffusion path, and promotes effective ion diffusion. The high capacity of the P-COF@SWCNT anode is attributed to the enolization reaction between the CO bond and K+ and the π-K effect (Fig. 7b). The composite of COF with conductive matrices such as CNT and the stripping of bulk COF improves the conductivity of electrode materials and high-rate battery performance, but it is also inevitable to encounter problems such as harsh synthesis conditions, complex experimental steps and low yield [24,70–72]. Therefore, the rational design of COF anodes should also comprehensively consider the redox active sites, electronic structure, thermal/chemical stability, and performance. Among them, regarding the conductivity of COF materials, Yang et al. [66] studied two-dimensional fully aromatic conjugated covalent organic frameworks (FAC-COFs) with high conductivity properties [73]. They developed a solvent-free strategy to prepare two phthalocyanine (PC)-based FAC-COFs (denoted as BB-FAC-Pc-COF and QPP-FAC-Pc-COF). By utilizing benzo[1,2-b:4,5-b′]bis[1,4]benzo-dioxin-2,3,9,10-tetracarbonitrile (BBTC) and quinoxalino [2′,3′:9,10]phenanthro[4,5-abc]phenazine-6,7,15,16-tetracarbonitrile (QPPTC) is formed by self-condensation in ZnCl2. Since the electrical conductivity of QPP-FAC-Pc-COF (1.94 × 10−4 S cm−1) is higher than that of BB-FAC-Pc-COF (9.27 × 10−5 S cm−1) and has a larger tunnel size. It can promote K+ transmission, so QPP-FAC-Pc-COF will be discussed later. It is precisely because QPP-FAC-Pc-COF has a fully π-conjugated electronic structure that enables good conductivity and a highly ordered structure that provides good thermal/chemical stability. The above advantages make QPP-FAC-Pc-COF useful as K-ion batteries exhibit higher battery performance when used as the negative electrode. QPP-FAC-Pc-COF showed a reversible capacity of 424 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.05 A g−1, and the capacity retention rate was close to 100% after more than 10,000 cycles at 2 A g−1, which is special, there is no obvious capacity attenuation. The ultrahigh electrochemical performance of QPP-FAC-Pc-COF depends on its four-step potassium storage procedure. Lee et al. [37] designed the structure of COF to improve the conductivity of COF and expose the difficult-to-use active sites inside COF. They synthesized fluorine-rich covalent organic frameworks (F-COFs) using 1,3,5-triformylphloroglucinol (TFP) and 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-1,4-phenylenediamine (F-DA) as monomers and utilized 1,4-phenylenediamine (DA) as a control sample. The presence of CF bonds in the F-COF framework helps enhance redox activity and conductivity and promotes the storage and transport of K-ions while inhibiting the decomposition of additional electrolytes. Also, the stronger average binding energy in F-COF compared to COF indicates that F-COF has stronger K affinity throughout the scaffold, resulting in better electrochemical activity and K storage capacity. Since the interface stabilization of F-COF exposes internal active storage sites, the experimental capacity of F-COF is close to its theoretical capacity. As a result, F-COF exhibits superior ion storage capacity and cycling stability versus pristine COF, which has a structurally similar configuration to F-COF. Notably, it sustains performance over 5000 cycles at 1 A g−1 without significant capacity loss. Different from Lee's research work, which introduced fluorine atoms into COF materials to enhance the interaction with K-ions, thus improving the utilization of active sites, Chen et al. [24] reported COFs with CO bonds and CN bonds for KIBs. A bulk COF (TQBQ-COF) containing triquinoxalinylene (TQ) and benzoquinone (BQ) units was successfully prepared, and demonstrated the introduced multiple redox active sites that can be efficiently utilized. Through theoretical calculations, it can be concluded that there are six suitable active sites in the TQBQ-COF unit to store K-ions (Fig. 8 a). After accommodating six K-ions, there are still negative sites both above and below the TQBQ-COF plane that can be used to store K-ions. Therefore, this TQBQ-COF has 10 K-ion active sites, resulting in a theoretical specific capacity of 429 mA h g−1. It is precisely because TQBQ-COF has multiple redox active sites (CO, CN and π-cation effect) that it has excellent reversible capacity compared with other potassium storage organic matter. Under a high current of 0.9 A g−1, the specific capacity is still as high as 147 mA h g−1 after 2000 cycles, and the capacity decays only 0.021% in each cycle (Fig. 8b). Due to the chemical composition and structural characteristics of the synthesized TQBQ-COF, it has excellent chemical stability in acid/alkali aqueous solutions (Fig. 8c). COF materials, connect by strong covalent bonds with porous crystal structure characteristics, could effectively alleviate the dissolution problem and significantly optimize the intercalation and storage performance of K-ions, so they have received extensive research and application attention in the field of KIBs as electrode materials. However, the low electrical conductivity of COF materials, the complexity of the synthesis process, limitations of crystallinity, and inefficient utilization of active sites have always been significant obstacles restricting their development. In view of this, developing more innovative improvement strategies to solve these inherent defects has become the key to promoting the in-depth application of COF materials in the field of KIBs. 4 Amorphous polymer electrode materials Amorphous polymer materials are also being studied as electrode materials for KIBs due to their facile and efficient fabrication compared to the crystalline material (Table 3 ). Similar to MOFs and COFs, amorphous polymers are also limited in practical applications due to their low conductivity. The π-conjugation or π-d conjugation extension on the polymer skeleton makes it have better physicochemical stability and electrical conductivity than that for the organic small molecule electrode [74–77]. Vlad's team, by introducing transition metal centers, designed and synthesized a one-dimensional linear polymer, K2-Co-PTtSA (PTtSA = benzene-1,2,4,5-tetra-methylsulfonamide) for KIBs cathode [81]. The extended π-d conjugated system between the metal and ligand exists in this polymer. It exhibits excellent conductivity, reaching as high as 10−6–10−7 S cm−1. This π-d conjugation interaction induces a change in the electron density of the ligand, consequently elevating the redox potential of the coordination polymer to 3.25 V (vs. K+/K). Stevenson and co-workers [83] used a similar method to introduce metal ions. They used 1,2,4,5-tetranaminobenzene as the linker and Ni2+ as the metal center to synthesize nickel-based coordination polymer (Ni-BTA) through simple agitation, and used it as the anode of KIBs (Fig. 9 b). The electrode achieves fast charging and relatively stable cycling, with a reversible capacity of 220 mA h g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 current density within a voltage window of 0.5–2.0 V (vs. K+/K), even with a capacity of up to 104 mA h g−1 observed at 10 A g−1. Tested at a current density of 1 A g−1, it can be stable for 200 cycles (Fig. 9c). The Ni-BTA electrode achieves superior cycling performance and reversible capacity due to its dual electron energy storage mechanism involving the CN/CN bond, in addition to possessing the redox capacity of conjugated ligands. In addition to the π-d conjugation formed by the interaction of metal d orbitals with the ligand π-electrons, there is also the structure of π-π conjugated polymerization of organic monomers which can improve the electronic conductivity and limit the solubility of the molecule. So far, the research of π-conjugated polymer electrode materials in K-ion batteries has been gradually advanced. Zhang and co-workers [80] designed and prepared π-conjugated polypyrene nanoflowers composed of microporous and mesoporous nanosheets through a simple oxidative polymerization process in Fig. 10 (a). The π-conjugated structure was designed in this polymer to enhance its insolubility, optimize its electronic conductivity, and improve its structural stability. The porous structure and two-dimensional interconnect nanosheets provide a large free space, shorten the charge transfer path, and enhance the ion diffusion dynamics. This work studied the oxidation/reduction processes of polypyrene and pyrene. The structural properties were analyzed using Density Functional Theory (DFT). Compared with the pyrene monomer, the HOMO-LUMO energy gap of the polypyrene polymer is smaller, indicating that polypyrene has stronger electronic conductivity and faster redox kinetics after polymerization. This is demonstrated by the two orders of magnitude higher conductivity of polyethylene and pyrene. Different possible potassium storage mechanisms can be obtained through DFT calculation as shown in Fig. 10(b). Combined with theoretical calculations and ex-situ FT-IR, it is concluded that the most likely energy storage mechanism is double electron storage on the same side of different benzene rings or on the same side of the same benzene ring with a central pyrene group. Due to the structural characteristics and excellent electrical conductivity of the polymer, the anode of the K-ion battery maintains an excellent reversible specific capacity of 302mA h g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 for 60 stable cycles. In addition, this polymer anode maintains a capacity of 190 mA h g−1 after 1000 stable cycles at a current density of 0.5 A g−1. 3,4,9,10-Perylene tetracarboxylic acid dianhydride (PTCDA), as a classic alkali metal cathode material, shows a promising application in K-ion battery cathode materials [84]. It can be said that the characteristics of small molecules and electrolytes hinder their application in the battery field. Lee and co-workers polymerized PTCDA monomer with carbon chains of different lengths to synthesize PTCDA-based polymers and effectively solved the problem of electrode dissolution through polymerization of carbon chain lengths of different lengths and electrolyte regulation strategies [85]. It is found that the electrode has good electrochemical performance when the length of the carbon chain monomer is 0, 2 primary amines (PTCDA-0C, PTCDA-2C) and the electrolyte is 5 M KTFSI DME. The electrodes of PTCDA-0C and PTCDA-2C are stable for 1000 cycles at a current density of 7.35 C, and the capacity retention rate is ∼100%. The functional groups of the ligands have a great influence on the potassium storage properties of the polymer electrode. Zhou et al. studied the oxidative reduction of potassium storage by polydiaminoanthraquinone (PQs) cathode [79]. The study found that with the substitution of electron-withdrawing groups (CN), PQ-CN exhibited a higher redox potential (from 2.0 to 2.4 V vs. K/K+) and a higher reversible capacity. The results of the DFT calculation show that PQ-CN has a low LUMO energy level and a small LUMO-HOMO energy gap (E g). The lower LUMO level indicates that the electrode material has higher redox potential and electron affinity. The extended conjugated structure with a reduced energy gap provides better electronic conductivity for PQ-CN electrodes. In addition to directly designing molecules to regulate the stability and electrical conductivity of organic compounds, the electronic structure of ligands can also be designed to regulate the electronic conductivity of polymer electrodes [22,26,86]. Conjugated microporous polymers (CMP) are a new kind of polymer framework [26,87,88]. Due to its highly adjustable active site, porous structure, and good electrical conductivity, it has a good application prospect in the field of electrochemistry [89–91]. Jiang and co-workers synthesized six CMP materials with conjugated structures. Through BET and electrochemical comparison tests, it was found that although high pore structure and high surface area provided large free space and abundant active sites for K ions, there was no necessary corresponding relationship between high porosity and excellent electrochemical performance [26]. The comparative study of the structure-performance relationship shows that the lower LUMO level and narrow band gap provide CMP with high electrochemical properties due to enhanced electron affinity and electrical conductivity. The possible potassium-storage mechanism of PyBT is shown in Fig. 10(c). Potassium is mainly stored in N and aromatic rings. The PyBT K-ion battery anode material provides a highly reversible capacity of 428 mA h g−1 at a current density of 0.03 A g−1 and exhibits excellent cycle stability at a current density of 0.05 A g−1, maintaining a capacity of 272 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles. The electrodes also exhibit excellent magnification performance. In addition, Liu's group [22] has further conducted in-depth research on the impact of the electronic structure of CMP on the performance of KIBs. They used 4,7-dibromo-2,1,3-benzothiazole (BT) and 1,3,5-triacetylene benzene as acceptors and donors, respectively, to construct a highly conjugated polymer BT-CMP with a layered interconnected porous structure. The BT-CMP has a narrow band gap and extended π-conjugated structure due to the strong electron absorbing ability and good plane structure of the BT unit. The redox mechanism of BT-CMP was also fully studied. When discharging, the K-ion first coordinates with the S-site at ∼1.2 V voltage, and then migrates to the N-site at ∼0.25 V voltage. The two-step coordination process increases the N-site reactivity of BT-CMP and promotes rapid complexation and release of K+ ions. The BT-CMP negative electrode in the K-ion battery shows a high capacity of 462 mA h g−1 with 100 cycles at 0.03 A g−1 and an ultra-long stability of 2000 cycles at 1 A g−1 current density (Fig. 10d). 5 The polymer composites To enhance the performance of polymer electrode materials, particularly the redox activity, relevant composites with the introduction of high-activity components, typically, sulfur species with high theoretical capacity (1675 mA h g−1) for K-ion storage, have been studied. Sulfur could be covalently bonded to the polymer skeleton for the sulfur-embedded composite, while functional groups or heteroatom within the polymer can minimize the diffusion and shuttling of polysulfides. Here we briefly summarize the applications of polymer composites in KIBs. Sulfurized polyacrylonitrile (SPAN) is the widely studied sulfur/polymer material with short sulfur chains, which is synthesized by heating elemental sulfur and polyacrylonitrile (PAN) under argon gas conditions (Fig. 11 a) [27]. It is identified that sulfur has been bound to the composite. In these systems, the charge and discharge process effectively involves the reversible cleavage steps of the CS bond and the parallel production of sulfides. Relying on XPS measurements, Sun et al. [44] further gain insights into the fundamental storage mechanisms of the K-S system. The reaction approaches could likely be expressed as follows. CSK + K+ + e− → C + K2S CSK + 2 K+ + 2e− → C−K+ + K2S (discharge process) C + K2S → CSK + K+ + e− (charge process) The CS bond in the SPAN electrode undergoes a complete redox reaction to form the final discharge product K2S. Therefore, for potassium storage chemistry, the smaller metastable S molecules have a kinetic advantage over cyclo-S8. The latter is considered thermodynamically unfavorable for the further reduction of K2S3 to K2S. Wu and co-workers [27] applied SPAN with a sulfur content of 38 wt% as the cathode material for K-S batteries with the use of a carbonate-based electrolyte. Ex situ Raman revealed that the electrochemical performance of S-PAN is attributed to the high reversibility of its covalent CS bond. SPAN provides a high reversible capacity of 270 mA h g−1 (0.71 Ah g−1 based on sulfur mass) at 0.5 C within a voltage window of 0.8–2.9 V vs. K+/K. A capacity retention of approximately 54% is attainable after 100 cycles. Analogous to the Li-S system, the utilization of a covalently bonded carbon host can minimize polysulfide shuttling. However, despite the absence of polysulfide influences, the issue arising from the potassiation reaction of the K anode persists, particularly in carbonate-based electrolytes employed in such systems. To improve the electrochemical performance of the SPAN cathode, Huang et al. [92] successfully prepared Se-SPAN by incorporating Se as an eutectic accelerator through ball milling and vulcanization treatment. Se significantly enhances electrical conductivity and sulfur utilization. Notably, the galvanostatic charge/discharge profile curves show that the discharge plateau and specific capacity of Se-SPAN are superior to those of SPAN. At 0.5 C, the initial capacity of the Se-SPAN electrode is 1294 mA h g−1, and it maintains 1120.9 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles, with a capacity retention rate of 87.4%, demonstrating excellent capacity and cycle life. To further improve the cycle performance of vulcanized PAN cathodes, Sun et al. [44] utilized poly(acrylic acid) (PAA) instead of the traditional PVDF binder. This modification improves adhesion, enhancing the structural integrity of the electrode and resulting in a more stable solid electrolyte interface (SEI) during long cycles. A reversible capacity of 1050 mA h g−1 was achieved in the window of 0.1–3 V with a retention rate of 95% after 100 cycles. Moreover, its capacity is further enhanced through methods such as doping, precursor modification, or sealing the reaction container. This highlights that the rational design of sulfurized polymer materials can enable them to show great potential in potassium batteries. SPAN has relatively low operating voltages and specific capacities in potassium batteries. Furthermore, the volumetric and gravimetric capacities of highly reactive potassium metals are inferior to those of lithium and sodium metals, so their practical application is limited. However, research shows that SPAN can provide potassium-ion storage capacities exceeding 500 mA h g−1 at a low cutoff voltage of 0.1 V (vs. K+/K). This is significantly higher than the capacities of reported carbon anode materials in a similar voltage range. However, due to the severe capacity attenuation, the subsequent operating voltage must be higher than 0.8 V (vs. K+/K). By building a protective and robust SEI, Zhu et al. [43] enable SPAN to provide excellent electrochemical performance in the negative voltage range of 0.1–2.5 V (vs K+/K). Within an anode voltage range of 0.1–2.5 V (vs. K+/K), the first reversible capacity of S-PAN is 610 mA h g−1 at 0.05 A g−1. Starting from the second cycle, the potassiation curve shows a decrease in polarization at potentials below 1.0 V (vs K+/K), and the main capacity can be obtained at voltages above 0.3 V (vs K+/K). S-PAN also exhibits exceptional long-term cycle stability with no capacity loss after 1500 cycles (Fig. 11b). Ex situ Raman revealed that the excellent battery performance of S-PAN results from the considerable reversibility of the CS bonds (Fig. 11c). The volume expansion of such S-PAN fiber after potassiation was ∼24.2% (Fig. 11d), which is significantly smaller than the 60% volume change observed in a graphite anode. Potassium storage in S-PAN stems was mainly from the solid-state insertion-extraction of K-ion. Although the high potassium desorption potential of S-PAN will inevitably reduce the output voltage of the corresponding full cell, its low volume change and excellent cycling stability make it highly potential as KIBs anodes. The electrical conductivity of the polymer composite material is critical for the irreversible transformation during the potassium storage reaction. In a recent study, Zeng et al. [21] reported a conductive organosulfur polymer (COSP) microcage that can be easily fabricated using microbial feedstock and elemental sulfur as precursors (Fig. 12 a). Unlike carbon–sulfur composites prepared by the traditional melt method, the two precursors undergo chemical skeleton reconstruction via decomposition and covalent bonding during thermal treatment, ultimately forming the organosulfur polymer. COSP contains 46.3 wt% sulfur species with abundant delocalized CC and CS groups (Fig. 12b). These delocalized CC and CS groups could effectively enhance electron transfer and result in high electronic conductivity (Fig. 12c). The short-chain sulfur is covalently bonded to the conductive polymer matrix through covalent bonds, which also effectively inhibit the formation of soluble polysulfides (Fig. 12d). When used as the cathode in K-S batteries, the resulting COSP exhibits an impressive reversible capacity of 1206.5 mA h g−1 and excellent cycling stability, with a capacity loss of less than 0.001% per cycle over 1100 cycles at 0.9 A g−1 (Fig. 12e). This work presents new perspectives on developing high-performance conductive organosulfur K-S cathode materials through a simple and practical protocol. 6 Summary and perspective This review summarizes recent progress on redox-active polymer electrode materials for KIBs, including MOFs, COFs, amorphous polymers and composites. The abundant active sites in the crystalline porous MOFs and COFs electrodes could be resistance to dissolution and facilitate efficient K-ion transfer during the cycling. Moreover, the MOF materials could be engineered into conductive and stable ones through π-d conjugation, and exhibit superb electronic conductivity and enhanced structure stability during the potassiation/depotassiation process, even at an extreme environment like high temperature (60 °C). In addition, the amorphous polymer materials without the requirement of crystallization, which could be fabricated facilitated and easy to scale up, have also demonstrated applied implications for KIBs. To enhance the redox activity of the polymer electrodes, the highly electrochemically active species could be introduced into the polymer networks via the covalent bond, typically, the chain sulfur species could be facilely bonded into the polyacrylonitrile via one-step heat treatment to get the sulfurized polyacrylonitrile (S-PAN). Its cross-link network structure of sulfur and polymer in these composites enables high reversible capacity and suppresses diffusion and shuttling of polysulfides. Notably, for the polymer electrode materials, there are environmentally friendly, resource-abundant, and high designability for the accessibility of higher level of functionality, for example, to build the conductive electrodes. Moreover, these polymer materials could suppress the dissolution issue and considerable structural flexibility for reliable chemical and mechanical stability. These attributions make the redox-active polymer materials highly significant applied implications for KIBs as potential anode or cathode materials. Despite their advantages in KIBs, the development of polymer electrodes in KIBs is still in its infant stage with challenges remaining. Below we discussed these challenges and proposed some research aspects. (1) The porous polymer electrodes like MOFs and COFs feature high porosity and large specific surface area, which usually lead to low initial Coulomb efficiency and more electrolyte consumption, because they would cause more side reactions in solid electrolyte interface (SEI) and consume more irreversible K+, The low Coulomb efficiency would make them far from satisfied for the full cell KIBa applications [93]. Furthermore, the unstable SEI would result in obvious electrochemical impedance increases during repeated charge/discharge processes, which is negative for the rate capability and long-term stability. It is expected that not only the control of the pore structure but also the electrolyte design will be important research subjects to optimize the overall performance of the polymer electrodes, particularly, the Coulomb efficiency. For example, it could be expected that utilizing electrolytes with a weak solvation structure can help to reduce the occurrence of side reactions, thereby enhancing the Coulombic efficiency and cycling stability. (2) The charge storage mechanism and structure–function relationship of polymer electrode materials, particularly the amorphous polymer and the composites, are difficult to elucidate well. For the amorphous polymer and the composites, it is very difficult to give their accurate structure due to the technical challenges. Therefore, more advanced or suitable examination and simulation means need to be sought or developed. The redox-active sites and structural evolution during repeated potassiation and depotassiation should be identified via the in-situ characterization. The elucidation of the charge storage mechanism and structure–function relationship would be significantly helpful for building the design principle for the advanced electrode materials for KIBs and even the beyond. (3) The electrochemical performance of batteries for practical application under extreme conditions, such as high temperature, low temperature, and lean electrolyte remains a significant challenge. In high-temperature conditions, there are not only aggravated mechanical and chemical instability of the electrodes but also more obvious side reactions on the electrolyte/electrode interface, such as electrolyte decomposition, particularly when considering that the porous polymer electrodes feature high specific surface area. On the other hand, in low-temperature environments, the diffusion kinetics of K-ion and electron are hindered, as the polymer materials are usually semiconductors or even insulators, resulting in decreased specific capacity and rate capability. Therefore, it is essential to build better polymer materials with not only higher robustness but also excellent conductivity to endure such extreme temperature conditions toward practical applications. Equally importantly, the innovation of the corresponding electrolytes and binders suitable for the polymer electrode is highly desired. (4) From the material design and fabrication point of view, it is essential to enhance the exploring efficiency and achieve large-scale production. The emerging artificial intelligence like machine learning could be expected to promote the boosting of finding high-performance polymer electrodes. Notably, for the amorphous polymer, machine learning may face significant challenges due to the deficiency of clear structure for the materials. In addition, the materials fabrication, particularly the MOF and COF is still in the laboratory stage with low productivity. The fabrication of high-quality products at the Kilogram level is still a difficult task, due to the strict reaction conditions usually needed, like non-water and non-oxygen environments, high temperature, and even high pressure. Developing methods that can fabricate the redox-active polymers at room temperature and atmospheric air environment, while achieving high yields of product, is of great importance. Equally importantly, the cost of the materials should not be ignored for promoting the scalable fabrication of the practical application of the polymer electrodes in K-ion storages. Ying Fang is currently a postgraduate at Jinan University. She obtained her bachelor's degree from South China Agricultural University in 2023. Her research interest is polymer electrode materials for K-based batteries. Lin Liu currently works at the Guangdong University of Technology (GDUT). She received her PhD degree from the Institute of Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences (ICCAS) in 2018. She then worked at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore as a postdoctoral research fellow. She joined GDUT in 2022. Her current research interests include the electrode and electrolyte materials for Li/Na/K-based batteries. De-Shan Bin currently works at Jinan University. He received his PhD degree from ICCAS in 2018. He then worked at the National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology as a postdoctoral research fellow in Japan. He started his current position as a professor in 2020. His current research interests mainly focus on the functional materials for K-based batteries.

coredata.dc:description: Benefiting from the low cost and high abundance of potassium resources, K-based batteries have attracted numerous research interest as a more sustainable battery chemist, particularly when considering the enormous demand for sustainable energy storage while limiting Li sources for Li-based batteries. However, the much larger size of the K-ion usually leads to the serious electrodes’ volumetric expansion with rapid capacity fading, making the pursuit of electrodes for potassium storage with high capacity and high stability a significant challenge. The polymer electrode materials have been considered promising materials to address these issues due to their porous characteristics, insolubility in electrolytes, and flexible structural design at a molecular level. In this review, we outline the recent advancements in redox-active polymer electrodes, including anode and cathode, materials for K-based batteries, including crystalline porous coordination polymers, crystalline covalent organic polymers, amorphous polymers, and polymer composites. We discuss the electrode designs, electrochemical performances, and K-ion storage mechanism, with a focus on their structure–function correlations. With this knowledge, we propose the perspectives and challenges in designing advanced polymer electrode materials for K-based batteries. We expect this review will shed light on the further development of reliable polymer electrode materials.
